segments.text: 45, 46,000 students.
Only, what, 2,500 of them in the Corps, approximately.
I don't know how many.
You've got all those others that we need to get involved in leadership training, and that's one of the great things about A&M.
We have it through these
great student programs that are being conducted through the Manoa Student Center and we need to give more attention to this and more funds to this and more help

uh in this area and uh if we don't doing it do it we're going to make sure that we we're we're not living up to uh the possibilities that this brings to us in my opinion let's see anything else yes keep going well stop in a minute so i can you know when
I was in A&M.
We had no art on the campus.
There was very little thought of art, performing, or any other kind.
We had Sully.
We polished regularly by a great artist, Copini.
But it was the only work of art besides folks here which a little later came along.
were artists in residence and did great work in giving the college some touch of art but this was recognized and we formed during Vandiver's time as president
a commission on the arts that was formed by him.
And this was made up of several people, quite a few people who were leaders.
George Connors, our friend in Dallas, Henry Gilchrist, John Lindsay, Sarah,

Fort Mundeley was quite a few people in the group and some of the staff members and we met regularly and we decided we had to have a art gallery, we had to have a art museum, we had to have more art on the campus and with Jim, with Wayne Starks backing and help we got something rolling on that and we thought maybe
we might break the ice with the great museum in Los Angeles.
The old man.
Getty.
Huh?
Getty?
Yeah, Getty.
We went out to see Getty Museum, talked to the director, and we hope that we might be able to, since he
got most of his wealth from under Texas, that he might recognize that and give some of these countless billions, just a few million, to A&M.
We never did accomplish that, but I think we could have had we followed it more seriously and concentrated more on it.
But we didn't by concentrating on it.
get the college to recognize we needed a gallery and put it in the path with the students and the Wayne Staub Gallery was a result.
Plus, we've already talked about the great work that Wayne did along with Jim Reynolds and
and others to bring the great collection of early American paintings built there on the campus of London.
And we got a start, but in addition to that, through Opus, we have had some notable successes in bringing the Russian ballet there.
That wasn't an accident.
General Reynolds was responsible for going there and selling that and bringing those men to campus to see how fluent they was and what a great facility we had in the Rudder Auditorium.
But we need more of that and we need to be, we need to get a art facility just like recently, I understand,
through the system we've tied into with A&M at the law school in Houston.
There's an art school we can tie into and have it tied in with us to give us some recognition in this area.
Because one thing the graduates of A&M lacked was some of the need
to know art and to what it is and have it part of your life.
And the graduate back in those days and even today is not getting attention in that area that he should have.
It's part of anybody's education.
And we need to recognize that.
Let's quit on that.
Huh?
Let's quit on that.
Were you through there?
Yes.
All right.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Dean Kyle, what did Dean Kyle mean to you?
Dean Kyle was the Dean of Agriculture and known, I think, throughout this country and this world as a leader in agriculture.
And he was part and parcel to most everything that went on at A&M because his voice was heard throughout the university.
And he took a very active interest in everybody in the agricultural school.
If I made the honor roll, I got a letter from him.
And my folks got letters from him.
And I have original copies if anybody wanted to see them.
He was very personal.
He made everything very personal.
And later in life, when I went
leaving Anderson-Clayton.
I had to decide where I was going to go.
This was right after I graduated and I told you the story about having to leave Anderson-Clayton because there was no work to do.
I looked around.
Dean Kyle was very active along with our old friend Sterling Evans and the Federal Land Bank, but
Of course we named the school for him and I needn't have mentioned him.
I mentioned polo, the Calvary and the romance of the Calvary and our polo teams when we were active regularly in that activity too.
I was a Rhodes Scholar nominee.
You never hear about a Rhodes Scholar at A&M, and I don't believe we've ever had a Rhodes Scholar.
I don't even know who the Rhodes Scholar nominees were over the years.
Do you?
No.
Somebody should look it up.
There have been some nominees, but I don't know who they were.
